title: Is it 'I walked so you could run' or 'I ran so you can walk', or are they both different things? - Quora

response.answer_text: These two sentences have different meanings. “I walked so you could run.” implies that one person, possibly a parent, did something for the benefit of another, possibly a child. He or she walked so the could would have the opportunity to run. On a less literal level, this sentence could mean that the parent worked very hard so that the child could have a benefit that the parent didn’t have, possibly higher education. With the second sentence, “I ran so you can walk”, the meaning I take from that one is, “I worked very hard so that you don’t have to work as hard as I did.” For example, a parent may have worked at a job involving difficult or tiring manual labor so that the child would have the opportunity for higher education and a profession that was not as physically difficult as the parent’s job might have been.

I'm not entirely sure the exact meaning of either without context. But they are different. The meaning of the sentences depends a lot on the specific meaning of both walk and run. “I walked so you could run" could mean: ᅳ I got things started so that you could succeed more quickly. “I ran so you can [could] walk" could mean: ᅳ I participated in a fund raising marathon to benefit organizations looking for solutions for your disability ᅳ I did more than I needed to do so that you can work at a leisurely pace. Would be glad to be more helpful if I had more context.
